item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Les Deux Soleils:  The Two Suns

The sunset is beautiful on this planet.  The double suns slowly dip down one by one into the horizon, like two gazing bright eyes.  When I was a child, I asked my mother, "Why are there two suns in the sky instead of one?"  My mother retorted, "Why do you have two hands, two feet, two ears, my dear?"  "But I have one nose," I replied.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Esperanto Lesson on Verbs

The endings -as, -is, -os denote the present, past, and future respectively.

Pluvas.  Pluvis.  Pluvos.
It's raining.  It rained.  It will rain.

Mi telefonas.  Mi telefonis.  Mi telefonos.
I am phoning.  I phoned.  I will phone.

Mi vidas.  Mi vidis.  Mi vidos.
I see.  I saw.  I will see.

It's just a little simple grammar.  Find out more about Esperanto at http://www.esperanto.net .

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
La Tandoor

I had a buffet lunch at an Indian restaurant called "La Tandoor."  It was only $6.95 and it included spicy chicken curry and all sorts of curry.  The dessert was rice pudding with pistachios.  It was a heavy meal, but it was fabulous.

A good thing that I notice of Indian restaurants is that the decor and the ambiance are very comfortable, almost like a bedroom.  It makes me want to take a nap after the hearty meal.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hmmmm, my last meal at Tandoori (here in Nijmegen) is some long years ago. The food was, like you say, spicey and very special. So were the host and his wife. We've had a very nice evening then.

Hmm, you make me want to go back.....now!!!!!!

Thanks for your nice comments!

Imbi
i love indian food
LOL...interesting analogy.

My wife and I go to Indian restaurants once or twice a week. I am British - so there is a history there between Britain and India. (Albeit, not very inspiring.)

But, Britain grew up with a lot of immigration from India to the U.K. in the 1970s - and there is virtually thousands of Indian restuarants across the U.K. now.

I fetched my liking for Indian food to the U.S. with me - and now my wife likes it too.

We go to a place that puts out fresh tandoori chicken for free, everytime we go in.

It is my favourite food...and it appears to be getting more popular in the U.S. now.

Thanks for the memory.
Mmm.. gotta love indian food.. nothing like home cooked though. -navdeep

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Electric Trees

I read in the newspaper about "electric trees" which could one day provide power and energy.  This idea comes from Bernard Witholt, chairman of the Institute of Biotechnology at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich.

Biotechnology would create plants that produce electricity from "sugars" or "photosynthesis."  The same machinery in electric eels could also be used by the new plants.

This is amazing!  I hope they make it true.  Imagine a grove of electric trees to power your house!

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Creating Languages

At the website of The Language Construction Kit, you can learn how to create languages.  The author says that the website "is intended for anyone who wants to create artificial languages-- for a fantasy or an alien world, as a hobby, as an interlanguage. It presents linguistically sound methods for creating naturalistic languages-- which can be reversed to create non-naturalistic languages. It suggests further reading for those who want to know more, and shortcuts for those who want to know less."

Like Singing

Check out my Vong website.  Vong is an art language, which I created under the inspiration of tonal languages like Chinese and Vietnamese.  There is a 1600-word vocabulary list, which I generated using the LangMaker word-generator tool.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Le Musée

Today, I went to the Anthropology Museum with my cousin.  The features were Islamic Art and Chinese Ceramics.  They were very beautiful.  Some pieces were really ancient.  There were also the regular exhibits of artifacts, mostly from indigenous peoples, from all over the world:  Asia, Polynesia, South America, North America, and Africa.

If I had capital like Bill Gates, I would have a house that looks like a museum inside, complete with glass cases and ancient artifacts:  masks, statues, tools, weapons, et cetera.  I already have a collection of some exotic articles from my various trips.

French...  Le musée est mon foyer. J'aime beaucoup d'habiter dans un musée.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
how come ancient artifacts from the indigenous peoples of the british isles are never in the anthropology museums of the world? perhaps because the british built their own museums. but hmm; their museums are mostly full of ancient artifacts from the indigenous peoples of other parts of the world. hee hee. go figure.

p.s. it's questions like this that made me quit my anthro phd program before i was even done with my masters. the whole question of history vs. anthropology; of a people telling their own story or having it told abt them w/out their involvement; the tradition of "othering" in that way is such sticky distasteful business to me. sigh.

tho ancient islamic art is amazing, isn't it? and it is wonderful to see it; that we can touch each others cultures even just that much. (did this comment go fully around 360 degrees, or what? LOL. this is, of course, always my goal)
probably does...

Oui le musée est un foyer de culture .

Amitié à vous               Michel

I love museums and ancient art, artifacts. Islamic art is a fav, too. I have a nice collection of art and weapons- mostly swords and medieval stuff- but nothing major. I have a friend who became an archeologist at the age of 52...she specializes in archeology of Israel and the Holy Land. All of her wonderful glass display cases for her curios and artifacts did nothing to save some of them from a small, but harmful, earthquake.*sigh* First order of business? Bolt them down! *chuckle*

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Viko:  An Art Language

yomavo'i vo
pa va polavasa da.
'a likiti va.

A tree:
Muscles break it.
Ah!  A noise.

Some people write poetry, some people write stories, but now some people write languages.  It's for serious fun.

Within a few days, I've created my own fantasy language for my own amusement and curiosity.  Inspired by the melodious sounds of Japanese and Polynesian languages, I've created this new art language Viko ("VEE-koh"), which has only 13 letters or phonemes.  Viko is a culmination of my ideas of minimalism, simplicity, and xenophilia.  I wanted to make it suitable especially for writing beautiful haiku poems.

At the LangMaker site, there is free software that allows you to create hundreds of words for your own fantasy language.  You may specify the structure, the phonology, of the words.  Suppose you want your fantasy language to sound somewhat like Spanish or Chinese; you can, with the free software, generate these words randomly.  It's amazing.  I've tried it and have created a 1600-word vocabulary for Viko in just a couple of minutes.  It's a lesson on surrealism...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: To phildynan:  I think people learn vocabulary more by seeing the words in context, in use, than going through a list of terms.  I would suggest that your friend pick up some magazines like The Economist or others with a political bent.  Her textbooks, though, if they are any good, should have glossaries.  Even then, learning vocabulary is a slow, osmotic process.  Cheers!

> On the Web you don't have to talk about football and cars.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Islandspeak

I'm doing a little reading on Pacific languages.  An amazing fact is that Samoan has only 14 letters:

a, e, i, o, u, f, g, l, m, n, p, s, t, v

Every Samoan word and every Samoan syllable must end in a vowel.  No two consonants can run together.  Samoan looks like this:

O le a 'ou talitonu i lena mea pe afai 'ou te ve'ai i ai.
I will believe that when I see it.

Afai e timu o le a le sau o ia.
If it rains he will not come.

Ae peita'i e to'atele o e ua muamua e avea ma mulimuli.
But many that are first shall be last.

The little sign ' is used to mark a glottal stop, like the catch in the throat between the two o's in 'co-ordinate'.  Samoans do get a lot of mileage with just 14 letters plus the '.

It actually is a rather simple phonological system.  English has a lot more sounds (phonemes) and consonants get clustered.  English phonology is a lot more complicated.  Samoan and other Pacific languages share a simplicity that seems fitting for their life in "paradise."  Ah!

French...  Oui, le paradis m'attend.  La simplicité des langues Pacifiques se perd dans la mousson de la modernité.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Tok Pisin

Tok Pisin is an English-based pidgin language, the common binding language of Papua New Guinea, where over 800 native languages are also spoken.  Here are some Tok Pisin lines from my newly bought book, Pidgin Phrasebook:

Mi lukim man ya i wokabaut long rot ya.
I saw a man who walked along the road.

Yu laikim suga?
Do you want/like sugar?

Taim san i go daun i gat bikpela singsing.
When the sun goes down there is a big feast.

Inap mi lukluk raun long ples?
Can I look around the village?

Turis i laik baim sampela samting.
The tourists would like to buy something.

wan, tu, tri. foa, faiv, sikis, seven, et, nain, ten
one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Interesting....you wouldn't by any chance be one of those people who know lots of random information?  I guess in your case random information about languages?

I think it's cool...keep it coming please
indeed, i would like some sugar, thank you. =0)

Cela ressemble à une traduction phonétique  de l ' Anglais .

It looks like a phonetic English translation .

To add some levity here, it sounds like mountain talk in Virginia/West Virginia. One can sort of pick it out if they speak s-l-o-w-l-y. Of course, I am a teacher of English and I am used to people "murdering" my native tongue! Have you noticed that most Americans speak in slang or cliches? When I teach non-natives to speak English, it is what we would consider formal speech and writing. Nice entry!

Wondering How long this language exist.
"Yu laikim pizza?" they are clever,they eliminated the "do" when making a question.
And the prononciaton,you pronounce what you read.
Ciao

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Toki Pona:  Choosing Simplicity

A fellow Esperantist on the Web, Christian Richard, has created his own surreal language, Toki Pona, as some kind of artistic endeavor.  Creating languages for fun seems to be a pastime for many Esperantists; I used to do this when I was a kid.

Mr. Richard writes:  "Toki Pona is a pidgin-like language designed to express basic human realities by reducing words and ideas to their most simple and universal meanings and avoiding unnecessary complexity. Inspired by the principles of Taoism and primitivism, the entire language has only 14 sounds and under 200 words."  What is amazing to me is that he was inspired by the virtues of simplicity in Taoism, something that I have also studied.

Mr. Richard further philosophizes about his creation:  "Toki Pona follows the principles of Taoism, which advocates a simple, honest life and noninterference with the course of natural events.  I have also been inspired by primitivists such as John Zerzan, whose writings critique the totality of modern civilization, recognising the superiority of natural, primitive cultures."

From looking at the phonology of Toki Pona, I can surmise that it is based on some Polynesian, island-culture language.  It only has the following letters and sounds:  a, e, i, j, k, l, m, n, o, p, s, t, u, w.

An example of Toki Pona follows:  "ilo suno wan li ken pana e suno tawa ilo suno mute mute. pali pi ilo suno li kama ala lili. tenpo la jan li pana e pona tawa jan mute, kama la pona li kama ala lili."  It translates to this Buddhist quote:  "Thousands of candles can be lighted from a single candle, and the life of the candle will not be shortened. Happiness never decreases by being shared."

Mr. Richard writes about the frivolity of his experiment:  "By being so general and vague, Toki Pona often lacks the ability to distinguish finer shades of meaning. For example, by lumping every possible bird species into one lexeme waso, we eliminate the need to learn hundreds of vocabulary items, however we are also left incapable of distinguishing between eagles and chickens. The closest translation might be an expression like waso wawa strong bird or waso nasa stupid bird.  Toki Pona has a rather narrow range of functions. Although it is very easy to communicate honest thoughts and everyday activities, it would be impossible to translate a chemical textbook or legal document in Toki Pona without significant losses. Such texts are products of the complex, artificial civilization we live in and are not suited for a cute, little language like Toki Pona."

Toki Pona is just for fun; it does not approach the more serious Esperanto.  Having read Mr. Richard's experiment, I have suddenly become interested in pidgin languages and have bought a book on the pidgin languages of Oceania.  Perhaps, one of these days, I will share some of what I have learned.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Ancient Egyptian, 1500-1400 B.C.

The Egyptian Book of the Dead, Section 15

Hymn to Osiris

Gratified is thy heart which is in Set, for thy son Horus is established upon thy throne. Thou art crowned as lord of Tattu as ruler in Abydos. Becomes green through thee the earth in triumph before the hand of Neberter.

Esperanto...

Kara Carlo:  You are right.  Translations of original works seem of little value such that I would rather read them in the original language.  But Esperanto has its own original thriving literature.  Your question:  Is it of any use?  Well, I learned Esperanto because of an appreciation of its architecture, as an artform.  With Esperanto, we have an alternative to the natural languages which are difficult to learn.  Take for example, when you learn French, you must conjugate a verb like être (to be): je suis (I am), tu es (thou art), il est (he is), nous sommes (we are), vous êtes (you are), ils sont (they are).  Now, in Esperanto, in the present form for all persons, it is the same:  estas.  It is much easier.  Esperanto is an easy alternative to the difficult natural languages.  It has a completely phonetic spelling system and a streamlined grammar.  Is it of any use?  Well, imagine if it could be promoted widely, then it would be easily attained literacy for many people.  Even native speakers of English struggle with the spelling and grammar of their own language.  Amike, Viktoro

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
In Search of Memes

There's this relatively new science called memetics.  It's very interesting and fashionable.  I don't think that everyone has heard what a meme is.  Impress your intellectual friends.  Here are some words from the Memetic Lexicon:

meme

"(pron. `meem') A contagious information pattern that replicates by parasitically infecting human minds and altering their behavior, causing them to propagate the pattern. (Term coined by Dawkins, by analogy with "gene".) Individual slogans, catch-phrases, melodies, icons, inventions, and fashions are typical memes. An idea or information pattern is not a meme until it causes someone to replicate it, to repeat it to someone else. All transmitted knowledge is memetic. (Wheelis, quoted in Hofstadter.) (See meme-complex)."

meme-complex

"A set of mutually-assisting memes which have co-evolved a symbiotic relationship. Religious and political dogmas, social movements, artistic styles, traditions and customs, chain letters, paradigms, languages, etc. are meme-complexes. Also called an m-plex, or scheme (Hofstadter). Types of co-memes commonly found in a scheme are called the: bait; hook; threat; and vaccime. A successful scheme commonly has certain attributes: wide scope (a paradigm that explains much); opportunity for the carriers to participate and contribute; conviction of its self-evident truth (carries Authority); offers order and a sense of place, helping to stave off the dread of meaninglessness. (Wheelis, quoted by Hofstadter.)"

meme pool

"The full diversity of memes accessible to a culture or individual. Learning languages and traveling are methods of expanding one's meme pool."

memetics

"The study of memes and their social effects."

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Interesting blog - it has great taste and is less filling.

hmmm - is 'meme' supposed to be a perjorative term? or can a 'meme' be true? is '1+1=2' a meme? this is very interesting stuff, i'm curious to find out more (despite being a lifelong dawkins-basher). thanks for a thought-provoking blog.

To yosha:  'Meme' is a neutral term, not pejorative.  And yes, '1+1=2' is a meme.  A meme can be true or false in value.  Buddha's First Noble Truth is a meme.

Cheers!

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Big Beautiful Earth

Well, I could be tooting my own horn, but I'm happy to have seen a lot of the world:  23 countries!  I feel contented.  I have seen great variations in people, customs, and language.  I should report that we truly live on a beautiful planet.

I was planning to see Greece next year, but with all the commotion in the world, that's up in the air.

Here's my list of the countries to which I've been:

Europe:  Spain, Portugal, Italy, Vatican, Austria, Germany, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Netherlands, France, England.

North America:  Canada, U.S.A., Mexico.

Asia:  Indonesia, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Hongkong, Japan, South Korea.

Africa:  Egypt, Morocco.

If I were to be asked which is my favorite country, I couldn't really answer because I enjoyed all of them.

Esperanto Lesson: 
Vivu la bela mondo! 
Long live the beautiful world!

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Poet and Poetess:  Sexism in Language

This blog arises from a previous comment by Juliet_A about sexism in language.

When in English we say, "All poets are dreamers," we automatically assume that poetesses are included.  So the word "poet" could either be masculine or sex-neutral depending on context, but "poetess" is exclusively feminine.  The masculine is used as default.  This is the same way in other languages like Spanish and French.  Even in the artificial language Esperanto, this holds true.  In Esperanto, the feminine of a noun is made with the suffix '-in':  poeto (poet) and poetino (poetess).

Then come the pronouns:  "As he or she is a dreamer, the poet is rather idealistic."  It seems rather awkward to say "he/she," "s/he," or "he or she" in English sentences.  The old prescriptive English grammar is that he, the masculine pronoun, could mean he or she in some cases, but this is old-fashioned.  In Spanish and French, it is this old-fashioned way that holds.  In Mandarin Chinese, there is only ta, which means "he/she."  Tagalog, the Filipino language, has siya, which means "he/she."  These Asian languages are less sexist than European ones.

In the Esperanto circles, there is a movement called Riismo ("ree-EES-moh"), which advocates the use of a new pronoun ri ("ree"), which means "he/she."  The Esperanto words for he and she are li ("lee") and shi ("shee").  Riismo also advocates a new masculine suffix '-ich' for symmetry with the feminine '-in', so that poeto is sex-neutral, while poeticho is male and poetino is female.  There is then balance and greater clarity.

Riismo is still highly controversial in the Esperanto movement.  I suspect that conservatives do not esteem it.  But Riismo shows that Esperanto can be non-sexist, while many ethnic languages, like English, cannot be fixed.

Ethnologue estimates that there are two million speakers of Esperanto.

item.dc:creator: viktoro

Soul Research

Of all the religions, I have a good idea about Christianity, Buddhism, Taoism, and Hinduism.  I've done some private research on these.  But I'm out of touch with Islam.  I know little about the beliefs of the Muslims.  I haven't read the Koran.  Even if I did, I'm not sure I could comprehend it.  I was at the university bookstore today and I browsed the Islamic holy book.  It looks complicated, like the Bible.  I read an article today in a French-language magazine about the mention of Jesus in the Koran.  In the Koran, Jesus is called "Isa."  It was an interesting article, but I realized how ignorant I am about Islam.

Je pense que je suis bouddhiste avec influence du Taoèisme.  Je pense que les plus grandes religions monothéistiques sont très compliquées.  Chez eux, il y a beaucoup de questions sans réplique.  Essentiellement, je suis heureux.  Je constate qu'il y a plusieurs années que ma famille chrétienne essait de me convaincre de leur foi, mais c'était inutile.

I felt that I had to write that in French.

The Way never interferes,
yet through it everything is done.
If leaders would follow the Way,

When reformed and desiring to act,

Undefined simplicity is free of desires.
Being free of desires, it is serene;
and the world finds peace of its own accord.

--Dao De Jing, Chapter 37

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
The Tao of What?

Has anyone read The Tao of Pooh by Benjamin Hoff?  It's an eye-opening book.  I learned a lot from it.  Here's an excerpt from pages 69-70:

"Just how do you do it, Pooh?"

"Do what?" asked Pooh.

"Become so Effortless."

"I don't do much of anything," he said.

"But all those things of yours get done."

"They just sort of happen," he said.

"Wait a minute. That reminds me of something from the Tao Te Ching," I said, reaching for a book. "Here it is--chapter thirty-seven. Translated, it reads something like, 'Tao does not do, but nothing is not done.'"

"That sounds like a Riddle," said Pooh.

"It means that Tao doesn't force or interfere with things, but lets them work in their own way, to produce results naturally. Then whatever needs to be done is done."

"I see," said Pooh.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Bridge over Troubled Water

Well, I'm pleasantly surprised that some of you have commented that war is not the answer to this calamity.  And those comments are coming from Americans!  Yes, we can hope for peace.  But what is transpiring seems inevitable.  The U.S. government has already declared war.  I suppose that they have to assuage the public that they are doing something.

Looking at the opinions on Xanga, I think that people are quite divided on the issue.  And this conflict could last years.

The terrorist network could be everywhere hidden in far-flung places like Uzbekistan.  Who really knows?  We don't know what they have planned.

What is happening is something fundamental to American society.  Suddenly, the troubles of the Third World are at the doorstep, at home.  For years, Americans have been living in a kind of Disneyland-Hollywood, sheltered in a "safe" paradise from the real pain in the Third World.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: On one hand, I think we should leave it up to God to be judge and jury. On the other, we have to set an example to those so that this doesn't happen again.

AMERICANS have always been aware and alert about conditions in other parts of the world. you talk often about peace on your site...and seem to have an idea or two about solutions. ??? unfortunatley, you also seem to have a rensentment for the U.S., it's implementation of foreign policy and, as you see it, prozac-induced oblivion. peace is not a term i would use if i was maligning a nation out of the other side of my mouth. please... fortunately, for me and AMERICA, i do not know any of these disneyland-hollywood individuals you are speaking about. therefore, there is no (that i know of) public that needs to be assuaged. our government does not have charge of a nation of barbarians. as you may have noticed, the largets AMERICAN concern over the past week has been the rescue of human life and the comfort of others in this time of tradgedy.

But different to Pearl Harbor, we had people killed NOT during a war/conflict, and those hit/killed were CIVILIANS! The goal of the terrorists was to CRIPPLE American economy and leadership. item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
War

Well, I couldn't believe it when I first saw it on TV:  planes hijacked, planes crashing into buildings as suicide bombs, the World Trade Center towers imploding from the crashes, and the Pentagon burning from a crash.  It seemed unbelievable, like something from a novel or Hollywood.  The first sights of the incident I saw at a pizza parlor in a university as students were huddled around a TV.  Later at home, I watched coverage on CNN from the U.S. and the French-language channel TV5 from Europe.

So is it this the Jihad, the Holy War?  I wonder.  Will it be tit for tat?  Here we are in the first year of the millennium and in a war.  How sad.

Buddha's First Noble Truth is that "all existence is full of suffering."

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I agree with you totally.. whoever did this will get messed with 10 times worse
Buddha was right.
Eprops to Buddha!

NONONONONO! There won't be any war! There can't be any war!! Not here!!

I refuse to believe there's going to be a war. I love this country and there's nothing that's going to stop me from it.

No war!!!
lets hope for peace!!!
War is the wrong way out of this.

A tribute to those who lost loves ones in the recent U.S. tragedy.

LIFE IS VERY PRECIOUS

Our lives we take for granted
when our days are smooth and free
when our years become a hundred
when we feel eternity

Then suddenly when life's cut short
disaster takes its toll
our world is torn by enemies
thru misery untold

We watch humanity crumble
with horror in our eyes
the terror of all we ever feared
and we're forced to realize

How life is very precious
so delicate and frail
we never know from day to day
when we'll face life's final trail

So live each day, like it's the last
for you never really know
when the kiss you give to the one you love
may be your final chance to show

How much you care, how you really feel
what you hold deep in your heart
share it now, before it's too late
before tragedy plays it's part

So much we take for granted
when our days are smooth and free
it takes a painful nightmare
to make us really see

How life is very precious
and loved ones can depart
so suddenly when we least expect
missed forever in our heart.

~  ~  ~  ~  ~  ~  ~  ~

LAST KISS

Little did I realize
when I held you tight last night
that it would be the very last time
for us to make our love feel right

Little did I realize
When I kissed you goodbye this morn
That I would never taste your lips again
And from my life you would be torn

Little did I realize
when I felt your last embrace
that it would be the last  smile I'd  see
from  your  gentle loving  face

Little did I realize
that your life would end today
that our love would end so suddenly
they'd be taking you away

Little did I realize
how much of you I'd miss
when you held me close within your arms
and gave me your last kiss

-

~ Tangerine ~

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Prophesies of Nostradamus

Nostradamus was a physician and prophet of the 16th century living in France at the time of the Inquisition. He wrote about 946 "quatrains," or four line poems, about his visions collected over his lifetime.  He wrote the following:

At forty-five degrees, the sky will burn,
Fire approaches the great new city,
Immediately a huge, scattered flame leaps up
When they want to have verification from the Norman
(Century VI, Quatrain 97)

In this phrase, Nostradamus refers to a great city in the new world of America near forty-five degrees latitude. Experts agree this could only be New York.

The king will want to enter the new city,
Through its enemies they will come to subdue it
Captives liberated to speak and act falsely,
King to be outside, he will keep far from the enemy.
Garden of the world near the new city,
In the path of the hollow mountains,
It will be seized and plunged into the Vat,
Drinking by force the waters poisoned by sulfur.
(Century X , Quatrain 49)

By fire he will destroy their city,
A cold and cruel heart,
Blood will pour,
Mercy to none.

Earth-shaking fire from the center of the earth.
will cause the towers around the New City to shake,
Two great rocks for a long time will make war,
And then Arethusa will color a new river red.
(Century 1,  Quatrain 87)

·»¤«· hea ·»¤«·
To IgoddessI:  I think language is *one* of the keys to human emancipation.  After language comes philosophy and politics needed for emancipation.

This speaks profoundly....and we in America are very egocentric in our living...we feel, sometimes (and incorrectly) that everyone should conform to OUR language and customs. Sigh.....I think this is a wonderful idea!

The principles in the manifesto are sound, but I am less impressed with the language, I find it to be sexist in it's derivative handling of females (a word that in itself is derivative, as is "women").  I guess I want more in a "perfect" language.

To Juliet_A:  But have you heard about a movement among Esperantists called "Riismo"?  It's an anti-sexist movement promoting the use of the pronoun "ri" (he/she) and the masculine '-icx' suffix for symmetry so that there is 'dentisto' (male/female), 'dentisticxo' (male), and 'dentistino' (female).  A language evolves through usage.  At least Esperanto can be fixed, English cannot.  See this site about Riismo:  http://www.rano.org/riismo.html

The ideas are good, very good, but the English are very stubborn and their minds are sculpted by the media. I know very few people who like the sound of joining the E.U. so as for sharing a common language - I don't think it will ever happen here!

Esperanto was created some years ago now - I found a site about people who spoke this language, but I know not a single person who can speak it.
hi hi

as a classical singer, i use most of the romantic languages on a daily basis. i don't neccessarily have a great command on any of these languages, but i could fumble through a conversation if i needed to. so, i'm not adverse to learning about other peoples, languages, customs, etc... i'm am, however, not sold on a homogeneous language, monies and the like. the whole point is that we are different and that is a wonderful and precious thing. when i go to france this summer, i don't want to think about american things like wal-mart, what oprah is talking about, at&t, mcdonald's, etc... i want to hear the french speak french, make french meals, tell french stories where i must fill in what i don't catch by watching their gestures and mannerisms...

as for world domination and power plays... the folks who want the power bad enough will have it. they will be sly and crafty. your best friend...allies. they'll talk about peace, equality and human rights until they are blue in the face. how much easier will power be siezed when there are no monetary, technological, linguistic and ideologic barriers? i'm not saying that the goals aren't good, noble and just. i wish for those things myself, but i don't think they will be accomplished by "unification" projects.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Dangerous Encounter

I'm reading a book in French, L'Afrique moderne, by Elikia M'Bokolo.  It's an interesting historical account of Africa.  A passage follows from page 9:

"A la fin du XVe siècle, au moment où la côte atlantique d'Afrique allait entrer en contact avec l'Europe, le royaume du Congo était l'édifice politique et social le plus puissant et le mieux structuré de l'Afrique centrale. Ce contact avec l'Europe devait être fatal: alors que les rois du Congo désiraient une 'cooperation' sur un pied d'égalité les Portugais cherchèrent et réussirent à déstructurer le royaume pour le placer sous leur domination."

Translated:  At the end of the 15th century, at the moment when the Atlantic coast of Africa was entering into contact with Europe, the kingdom of the Congo was a political and social edifice most powerful and best structured in central Africa.  This contact with Europe had to have been fatal:  while the kings of the Congo desired a 'cooperation' on the foundation of equality, the Portuguese sought to and succeeded in destroying the kingdom for placing it under their domination.

I learned quite a bit.  I didn't know the Portuguese had so much influence in Africa.  They were on the western and eastern coasts of Africa.  I know Angola and Mozambique today speak Portuguese, but if the Portuguese had more staying power, today most of Africa would be speaking Portuguese.  The Congo area was later colonized by the French and Belgians, and today that whole region has French as the official language.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Ringworld

I'm rereading a fascinating book I read back in high school; it's Ringworld by Larry Niven.  It's about adventures on a world shaped like a vast ribbon around a sun, about as vast as the orbit of Earth around its sun.  On the edges of this ring are thousand-mile walls to hold in a breathable atmosphere.  On the surface of this ring facing its sun are continents, mountains, seas, oceans, rivers, forests, and deserts.  Ringworld has a surface area of three million Earths. The ring spins at a speed that produces one gravity on the inner surface.  To simulate day and night, there is a ring of alternating shadow-producing black squares in an orbit much closer around the central star. A very technologically advanced race created Ringworld, a sophisticated engineering marvel. How does Ringworld compare with the Great Pyramids or the Great Wall?

Back in high school, I used to fantasize about this Ringworld.  I used to look at a soccer field and imagine it was a plain on Ringworld.  I used to bike near the riverbanks and imagine the river was part of Ringworld.

The picture shown is from near the surface of Ringworld.  A part of the ring can be seen arching into the sky.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Kimonos and Neon Lights

"Japan Rocks."  In bold letters, that's what you see on the front cover of the technowizard Wired magazine, Issue 9.09 (September 2001).  The feature asks:  "Is Japan Still the Future?"  It's a rethink on the futurological mysticism about Japan.  There's an interesting article by William Gibson, the famous science fiction author who wrote Neuromancer.  The article expounds on why Japan is still the Future.  It's the kind of analysis about Zeitgeist sociology that I don't see anywhere else in the media.  Most in the media are black and white about Japan.

Back in the 1980's, Japan was synonymous with the future:  the neon lights, the robots, the gadgets, et cetera.  Then in the 1990's, the Bubble burst; it was a decade mired in recession.  Suddenly the beacon of the future seemed no more.  In the meantime, the United States was prospering.  But now the U.S. is in pseudo-recession.  I think because of this, a few Americans are rethinking Japan.  The echos seem faint, but familiar.

I have been to Japan nine times, mostly to work.  I have seen that remarkable country.  One has to view that country beyond mere economics, which is cyclical anyway.  There, I have seen both the future and the past, the skyscrapers and the kimonos, the bullet trains and the ancient temples.  It's a contrast that I have seen there in everyday life.

What about the future?  Let me digress a little.  I see Japan and the United States as advanced countries in a consumerists' frenzy.  Buy this brandname thingumajig.  Sell that brandname gizmo.  When the stockmarket and the GNP (Gross National Product) go down, the economists and businessmen are depressed, and the headlines tell everyone else they should be depressed about it too.  It's a rollercoaster.  Is the future merely more of this same worldview?  I'm hoping for a major paradigm shift one day.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: one thing i enjoy about coming to your page is you constantly make me stop and think about things.

i know this might not relate to what you are talking about but something has just crossed my mind... even though i've never been to japan. i would love to learn more about japan but at this moment i know nothing much of the history or the present... just the wonderful art and food but i think Japan is more prosperous than we are in the United States. i think it's due to japan's total respect for the past as well as maintaining part of the past (traditions/ rituals/ beliefs ...etc.- that are of course still accepted in their society) as a way of living a better life.  not in the sense of government, freedom, vast opportunites  or how multicultural we are in the States, but more on the realm of them advancing so quickly to the future in a more ....what's the word i'm thinking of...i guess in a good way.  of course having the right resources and knowing how to optimize these resources prospers any country .... but i think combining the past and distilling it into the future will make a country grow faster. in addition a country that has similar past as whole, understands and respects the people - thus they prosper together.  whereas in the states..... the society is so diverse  that's a great thing because we become more open-minded and more well rounded... but because everyone were brought up with completely different belief systems, the diversity somehow create an imaginary line between the people. people with the same culture tend to gravitate together thus forming huge communities of  their culture creates such a line. thus causing someone to disagree, boycott, challenge the system. thus making it difficult to understand one another, difficult to satisfy everyone, and difficult to prosper. they could only do what's best for the people ....  but somehow someone suffers because theperson that suffer can't survive just based on  the "best of the people"   i guess that happens to any country or society...."survival of the fittest" .... i'm not saying or making the united states look bad making it seem as if it is a horrible place to live .... i'm blessed to be alive and breathin in a country that's ironically at peace with itself. i'm blessed to be in a country that has so much to offer to the people. the question was .... is japan the future? i think so ... the states are the future as well but i think the states may be in a differentt realm of the future.. i don't know what kind of future the states may fit into though . you know i'm rambling on and on.... i might be saying things that i might even regret or things i might not even believe in a day or two later - it's a "what if" thought hehhe  am i making any sense at all?...  you know i could be wrong on this .... what do you think?

To LuLuLuChia:  Well articulated.  I get the gist of your thoughts.  I enjoyed reading it.  Yes, Japan has a great ancient heritage that still lives on in the present and in the future...  It is like wine.
I really really hope to go to Japan someday. Its a remarkable thing about the people and the work ethics. They are really really driven, which is a trait I would like to have.

Also, I do keep hoping that the trend toward commercialism will deteriorate at some point.

Interesting, we're caught in the Western concept of linear time and the future being *ahead* of us.  We're also part of a thought system that considers more as better, bigger, more *advanced* (especially technologically).  Hmmmm.

Subvert the dominant paradigm.  That's all it is.  Dominant.  Here and now.  There are other ways, after all. 

Peace.  ~Paloma

However it is my belief that it will not always be so harmonious and that one day the whole system will collapse with horrendous consequences. It will be a mournful time, but hopefully one in which great change will follow.

This sort of attitude makes people believe that Japan is always on cusp of technological change.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Twilight Zone

I've been reading about biology these days. Watching Planet of the Apes has piqued my interest.  Trying to kill two birds with one stone, I read a book on cell biology in French, so I could review both biology and French.  The funny thing is that it seemed easier to read scientific literature in French than reading a novel in French.  The grammar in scientific literature is more straightforward than that in a novel.  I am not fluent in French, but after a year of practice in reading, I have greatly improved my reading skills!

Anyway, I read something about animal hybridization from another book at the university.  The book was in English!

The mule is a hybrid of two species.  A mule is the offspring of a mare (female horse) and a jackass (male donkey). The offspring of a male horse (stallion) and a female donkey (jenny) is called a hinny. The chromosome number of a mule or hinny is 63.  A horse has a chromosome number of 64, while a donkey has a chromosome number of 62.  The mule is sterile.

Se mi povus trovi sciencan libron en Esperanto, mi volus legi ghin.  If I could find a science book in Esperanto, I would like to read it.  Mi pensas ke Esperanto taugas bone por scienco, krom arto.  I think that Esperanto is well suited for science, besides art.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Glow-in-the-dark Animals and Plants

I'm really amazed by the new work on genetic engineering these days.  There is a rabbit that is gene-spliced with jellyfish, so the rabbit actually glows in the dark under black light.  The jellyfish is naturally luminescent in the dark seas.  It's a designer rabbit.  It's true.

Scientists are even working on glow-in-the-dark grass. Imagine your lawn glowing in the dark!

There are all sorts of complex moral and philosophical issues involved with genetic modification.  It will be interesting.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: poor rabbit... i bet it's confused... i would be if i glowed in the dark... although that would be pretty cool, i can't help but wonder, if we can have "designer" rabbits, how long until they start making designer people...it's scary.
Scary yet fascinating all at the same time!!!

Sometimes I wonder - did people say the same things as new medicines were being created?  Cosmetic surgery?  Every medical advance has been scary - but when do we stop?  Do we do things just because we've discovered we CAN?

'interesting' is one word for it, though i'd agree with other comments that 'scary' would fit quite well. the glow-in-the-dark rabbit is so silly and surreal that i'm inclined to think maybe someone's taking the piss. i'm also reminded of a song by a forgotten british band called new model army: "how do we tell the people in the white coats that enough is enough?"
Morality aside, Glowing rabbits and grass, cool.  But, who really needs such things?

I wonder if other rabbits would react favorably to a glowing rabbit?  is this a dominant trait that would be passed on to future generations, or is this animal such a freak it can't reproduce?

I don't think research in this area needs any restrictions, the net result can only make the world a more exciting place in which to live.
i am mesmerized!
interesting is not the word that first comes to my mind, unfortunately...perhaps.
*hugz*
Glow-in-the-dark grass sounds interesting.

Oh, I made a mistake! I am very sorry.
I'd glow in the dark if I could. =)
glow in the dark grass..that could be interesting...i would be able to see if it need a cut even if its dark!
Hell yeah!   This stuff is so sweet.  Let science take us wherever it goes.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Information Product

I seldom read the newspaper.  When I do, it takes me about five minutes and it's over.  The articles are just not too interesting.  In this day and age, surfing the Web is more fun while looking for information in which I'm interested.  Or in the old-fashioned way, I like to curl up with a well-written book rather than waste time with the newspaper.

One thing that most people don't realize is that the newspaper is a product, a very commercial item.  The stories therein are made to sell to a mass audience with the lowest common denominator.  Not only that, it gives one a worldview that is generally negative, a distorted view of reality.  I think that is the "reality" most people have.  It is unfortunate.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Looks like we were on the same wavelength today regarding the media.
Agreed my friend... I quit watching the news and reading newpapers about six months ago and my mental health is much better as a result!!

Yes, I agree...the news is very depressing to me. I've read the paper lately, and the first article said. the guy was convicted for raping a young woman.

Then (a diff article I read later on) that they exhumed a body from 1970, in which the victim had been strangled and and her body left in a pond.. again another young lady. The reson for exhuming th ebody, was that in the hope that science and how it has progressed in the past 30 years, more clues could be assesed.

The news? So very down.

~Erin~
Aren't books and Internet too mostly products of capitalism?
To mike22651:  At the least on the Web, ordinary people can publish their thoughts.  It's different from books and newspapers wherein a certain reputation must be had by the writers.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Campus Spirit

The last two days I visited my old university.  I walked around the tree-filled campus.  I admired the aging buildings of the Main Library, the Math Buildings, and the Chemistry Building.  They had that Old World ambiance of grey stone and crawling ivy.  It felt as if I were a tourist in some quiet European town.  It was magical.

But there were also some new buildings around.  It looks like the university has had a lot of funding for new construction.  I found my alumni pictures in the new Computer Science building.  I was so happy to see my picture up on the wall.

Moreover, I just enjoyed the weather.  It was blue skies and sunshine.  Warm breeze was whipping across my body as I walked the hallowed alleys between the buildings.  The mountains and the sea were a beautiful backdrop.

I decided I should visit more often.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Planet of the Apes - movie, 3 stars

Planet of the Apes is a remake directed by Tim Burton.  This is a movie that I have been anticipating since last year.  I have seen the original, so I am inclined to compare.  In this remake, the sets and costumes are very well made.  There have been some noticeable improvement on the "apeness" of the apes themselves in the way they act and gesture.

A glaring change, which I noticed, from the original is a sociological statement on mixed-race relations.  In the original, chimpanzees mated with chimpanzees, gorillas kept to themselves, humans mingled with humans.  Also, there was a class system based on species:  oragutans were administrators, chimpanzees were scientists and thinkers, gorillas were warriors, and humans were slaves.  But in the remake, the races are all mixed up:  orangutans mate with chimpanzees; there is an interesting love triangle involving one man, a woman, and a female chimpanzee.  Do we get the hint?

One thing that detracts from this remake is ample servings of humor.  The original was serious, deep, and philosophical.  This remake is a lot lighter, but the humor "cheapens" it.  I like serious movies.  There are also some corny scenes in this remake.  The ending is really corny.

[Picture disappeared]

Blissymbolics: "I want to dwell in the countryside."

What's that in Esperanto?  "Mi volas loĝi en la kamparo."

I used to like the energetic crowds of the modern city.  I had a stint in Tokyo and liked living there.  I remember the extravagant, bright neon lights and the outwardly chaotic, but essentially orderly, busyness everywhere.  But I think I got that out of my system.  Now I like the quiet, uncrowded towns, even empty rural places, especially near mountains like the Alps.  But I could settle for a slow-paced, uncrowded, tree-filled, antique-filled city like Vienna, Austria.  I'm dreaming.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Double Sun

In the guestbook, JDMoore wrote a stunningly apt description of the picture on my profile:  "A very beautiful picture of a planetscape under two G stars. Keep the Faith!"  Two G stars are exactly what they are.  A G star is a white-yellow star like the sun.  I wanted to see what a world would look like with two suns, so I added two suns onto the picture of the shore.  I want to be in a world like that.

On a street near my house, there is a restaurant named Cafe Deux Soleils (French for "Two Suns Cafe"), which should not be confused with another cafe, on the same street, called Cafe du Soleil (French for "Cafe of the Sun").  They sound rather similar if you are familiar with French pronunciation.  (Please excuse me for not putting the acute accent over the 'e' in 'cafe' as I don't like using accents.)

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Thai Year

When I visited Thailand a while ago, I discovered that the Thais used a different year reckoning.  Our year 2001 is the Thai year 2544.  Just add 543 years to our year.  Thais reckon their years since the Enlightenment of Buddha, 543 B.C.  So while the Western world is in the 21st century, the Thais are in the 26th century.

Thai Numbers

[Picture disappeared]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I like that! I'm always up for learning something new!
Oh, dear - makes me feel so very unenlightened! ;)
How intriguing....
Very interesting...
Time is relative.
those things look evil. i think they may be trying to take over the world. or maybe just ruin my buzz.

I actually have a friend who is from Thailand.  She works at my school and she tells me, in very beautiful English, that I am the only student she will ever allow to call her Sasamon, which is her Thai name.  She thought to teach me Thai, but somehow we never got around to it, so I hope we may start this year.  She is an interesting person, and quite beautiful, and her original language suits her much better than the rough and gutteral language I speak. I only wish I understood her.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
A Beginning

Being in 2001 feels like a fresh beginning.  It is not like living in the 1990's when it was the end of something, the end of a century, the end of a millennium.  Now it is a beginning.  I like it better in the first half of a century.  It feels calmer, less hurried, less panicky.  It is a fresh start into the third millennium.  It is all in the numbers.  It is psychological, subjective.  When 2010 or 2020 rolls by, it will still feel that way to me.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Is Time Fast Or Slow?  Is Life Short Or Long?

X, someone I know, thinks that time is fleeting:  days pass like minutes.  I was surprised by her thinking.  For me, time seems adequately slow.  However, X thinks that life is long.  It sounds like something is askew in her thinking:  time is fast, but life is long.  I think that it makes more sense to think that [A] time is slow and life is long, or [B] time is fast and life is short, but not [C] time is fast and life is long.  I think that I am of the type A.

W, someone I know, thinks that life is all about competition and money.  That thinking is so foreign to me.  To me, life is about exploration.  I'm a little suspicious of this W.

Y, someone I know, doesn't think that life is all about money.  Y thinks life is all about career.  Y always talks about his career.

Z, someone I know, is really a philosopher.  Z works to survive, but wouldn't work if he didn't need to.  Aren't many of us like that?

W, X, Y, and Z are real people in my life.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: As far as I'm concerned, time is fast and life is short. I think like this because of my age.(I'm in my 30's) You who think "time is slow and life is long" must be very young.

Something to think about...

Tracey
So Very True.
I, too, think time is fast and life is short. And of course I wouldn't work if I didn't have to! I would get a  whole lot more reading done!
I don't know...C makes sense to me...When you have no idea where your day went time is fast, but life is long because you have many more days.

I am Mrs. Z.  My husband is W.  I the type that lives for the minute and makes plans day by day.  He looks to the future with long term plans and expectations dealing with money.  When you put us together, however, we just work out.

depending on what situation, time is fast or slow, and depending on every living creature, their life can be long or short...my philosofie...you got me thinking man!

Malou

...isn't it all an illusion anyway?

All that exists is present in this momment.
Our past, present and future all exist right now. So, what more is there then the momment? Our determining fast or slow, long or short is merely a perception and how we choose to see.

Cool.

I could go into great detail on this one.  Hmm. Where would I even begin. Time is fast, from our perspective, our life is short.  By the time we're done, all our time is gone, really quickly. But when you think of it in relation to the rest of time, no matter how fast time goes, there's an infinite amount of it out there. So life is infintesimally short (and brutal) and fast.  And time is extremely fast, but infinitely long.

As for the past present and future? We should make the most of our present, because our past is what got us here, and what we do with this moment will determine our future. 

I have a friend who thinks life and everything is pointless. She goes into cataclysm's trying to explain her point.  I tell her, that her point in life is to explain its pointlessness. She's stuck. 

I think that its important to work. To make money, to live, to do things. Our work contributes to our civilization.  It improves the life of our civilization.  Some of us are meant to sit by and philosophise, but most of us are meant to work, and think about what the philosophers say.  The way our life will become long and slow, in a time that is short and fast, is if we think of our infintesimal contribution to it as being part of a greater bigger 'life' that of our civilization.

I think it's all relative.  Right now, with Mike away, time is slow - but life is long and stretches away like a long meandering road.  Sometimes time is fast and life seems far too short but right now, it's definitely the other way round for me.
I think time passes too quickly.  I wish I could have like a year of frozen time where I sat alone in front of my computer.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
A Deep, Philosophical Dream

I had a philosophical dream last night.  I was talking about religion with people who had a Christian worldview.  Paraphrasing, I asked them, "How can an omni-benevolent God create all the misery in the world?  How can an omni-benevolent God coexist with all the misery in the world?"

Then in the dream, someone asked me, "What's your religion?"

I said, "I'm a Buddhist-Taoist."  I've been reading about Buddhism and Taoism in my waking life.  It seems that in my dream, I affirmed my new-found spiritual stance.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Philosophy of Life

(A friend passed this on to me via e-mail...)

A philosophy professor stood before his class and had some items in front of him. When the class began, wordlessly he picked up a large empty mayonnaise jar and proceeded to fill it with rocks, rocks about 2" in diameter. He then asked the students if the jar was full.

They agreed that it was.

So the professor then picked up a box of pebbles and poured them into the jar. He shook the jar lightly. The pebbles, of course, rolled into the open areas between the rocks. He then asked the students again if the jar was full. They agreed it was. The students laughed.

The professor picked up a box of sand and poured it into the jar.  Of course, the sand filled up everything else.

"Now," said the professor, "I want you to recognise that this is your life. The rocks are the important things - your family, your partner, your health, your children - things that if everything else was lost and only they remained, your life would still be full. The pebbles are the other things that matter like your job, your house, your car. The sand is everything else, the small stuff. If you put the sand into the jar first, there is no room for the pebbles or the rocks. The same goes for your life. If you spend all your time and energy on the small stuff, you will never have room for the things that are important to you. Pay attention to the things that are critical to your happiness.  Play with your children. Take time to get medical checkups. Take your artner out dancing. There will always be time to go to work, clean the house, give a dinner party and fix the disposal. Take care of the rocks first - the things that really matter. Set your priorities. The rest is just sand."

But then...

A student then took the jar which the other students and the professor agreed was full, and proceeded to pour in a glass of beer.  Of course the beer filled the remaining spaces within the jar making the jar truly full.

The moral of this tale is - no matter how full your life is, there is always room for BEER.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
[Picture disappeared]

"That is my house."

What are Blissymbolics?

Originally designed by Charles K. Bliss as an international language, Blissymbolics are "an alternative graphic symbols system that individuals with severe speech and physical impairments find much easier to learn and use than traditional print." Blissymbolics have been "used extensively since 1971 as a primary mode of communication for non-speaking people with cerebral palsy."

Does Esperanto, the aspiring International Language, have competition here?  Well, for one thing, Blissymbolics are not pronounceable, being a completely visual language.  At least, one could speak and listen in Esperanto.  And Esperanto uses Roman letters just like English.  Blissymbolics are more like Chinese than English.  Blissymbolics definitely have a niche though.  Anyway, I think the Blissymbols are quite beautiful.  They would look cool on a T-shirt!

More examples of Blissymbolics...

[Picture disappeared]

"Time is measured in hours, minutes, and seconds."

[Picture disappeared]

"She has beautiful teeth."

ZPG

I read from http://www.overpopulation.net/  that the world population will hit zero population growth between 2020 and 2029.  This is also known as ZPG ("zee pee gee" for Americans and "zed pee gee" for Canadians):

"The exponential growth of human population peaked in 1987. That year 87.01 million more people were added to the Earth. Since 1987, the population has declined on average by 2.1 million less people added per year. In this year of 2000 the population will increase by 60.1 million people. If we maintain this 13 year average of 2.1 million less people added per year, we will peak in population reaching zero population growth in 2029 with 6.90 billion people."

I think ZPG is good news for Mother Earth and us humans in general.  Maybe even a decrease in population later will mean quieter streets and towns all over the world.  Pli kvieta.  (Quieter.)

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Tubers

My mother asked me to buy sweet potatoes in the market for the family barbecue this evening, but instead bought yams.  I thought they were nearly the same, but I researched the Web and found out that yams (Dioscorea spp.) and sweet potatoes (Ipomoea batatas) were not even in the same genus.  Well, they're both good anyway.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Not a bad mistake to make!
They are both good and i also thought the same thing for years.
I didn't know there was a difference either! Thanks for the cooking lesson. :)
Haha, easy to mistake.  Funny

When I was growing up, some members of my family insisted that sweet potatoes & yams were NOT the same things, while it seemed the rest of the world were saying they were indeed one in the same.

Oddly enough, those same family members used the word "mango" when referring to a sweet pepper. haha.
I was an adult by the time I found out I do indeed like mangos. haha.

Tomorrow on Victoro's Weblog - Tomatoes are NOT vegetables!
;) hehe.
I though they were the same too!  Imagine, after all these years learning that.
Wow... thank you for enlightening me-- learn something new every day!  (And, this was definitely the one thing I did learn today, hehe!)

Not only are they not the same genus, they're not in the same family! Sweet potatoes are in the same family (in fact, same genus) as morning glories, but yams have their own family. According to Plants For A Future, edible species of yams have opposite leaves, but yams with alternate leaves are poisonous. Another difference is that yams are modified stems (like potatoes), but sweet potatoes are enlarged roots.

Just thought you'd be interested.
Ah...ninth grade bio

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Unicode

As an amateur linguist, I am fascinated with the massive effort of the computer industry to unify all the writing systems of humanity into one standard--the Unicode Standard. Unicode contains all the scripts: Western European, Eastern European, Cyrillic, Greek, Turkish, Arabic, Hebrew, Ethiopian, East Indian, Native Indian, Thai, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, et cetera--basically everything. Unicode enables computer programs to easily manipulate data from all living languages using one character set.

Of the 94,140 characters in the newest version of the standard, 70,207 are unified Han logographs--slightly more than 75% of the encoded characters in the standard. Han logographs are Chinese-derived characters used in Chinese, Japanese, and Korean.

Propagating Unicode is a step in creating a linguistically democratic, worldwide electronic infrastructure. There's an underlying philosophy in the Unicode effort; it's one of democracy, unity, and respect for all humanity and its variations. It will be a matter of time before Unicode is ubiquitous, but it's already widely used in the industry.

I want to read up more about it.  Vivu Unikodo!  (Long live Unicode!)

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
The Tao of What?

Well, I read The Tao of Pooh by Benjamin Hoff.  This marvellous book was recommended by rdolivaw.  It stars Winnie-the-Pooh and his gang.  Basically, the book expounds in simple words the tenets of Taoism, in which I have become interested recently.  I like the philosophy of wu wei (non-doing), in which one does not struggle against the stream or flow of nature.  And Pooh does non-doing (wei wu wei) so naturally.

Also, I recently read a translation of Tao Te Ching (or Dao De Jing), a 2500-year old text about Taoism.  It really opened doors for my mind.  I was so impressed by this Chinese work.  I wish that I could read the original in Chinese.

Speaking of Chinese, I took eight weeks of Cantonese once, and eight weeks of Mandarin, but I just scratched the surface.  I learned to read some logograms on my own.  There are just a bewildering number of logograms to remember, too many.  Esperanto estas multe pli simpla.  (Esperanto is much simpler.)

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Incubus

Starring William Shatner (also known as "Captain Kirk" from Star Trek), Incubus is the one and only American film made entirely in Esperanto, the aspiring International Language.  At the Incubus website, you can actually hear Shatner speak in this artificial language in this occult film made in 1965.  It's amazing that Esperanto ever got that much publicity in the United States.  The film was subtitled in English.  Esperanto was selected to impart a supranational ambiance to the supernatural beings in the story.

I have not seen the movie myself, but am glad to hear about this little bit from the history of Esperanto.  I would like to see it when I get the chance.  Shatner's accent was not too bad from hearing the sound bite.

To Juliet_A:  I guess that I really meant to say "pronunciation" of the words, not really the "accent."

Hola, kia ist vi (I think that's it, hehe)

Getting back to the accent stuff... is the Esperanto learned in the US different from the one here or anywhere else in the world? I mean, because of our native language it must have some tipical accent, which could make it more difficult to understand it worldwide. As it happens in Latin... To listen to an English native speaker speaking Latin, is very weird... at least that's the way it sounds for the people who have latin as the basis of their current language.

:^)

To GaucheAngel:  Saluton!  Kiel vi fartas?  (Esperanto for:  "Hello!  How are you doing?")

When one is learning a new language, there is often the influence of the mother tongue in the pronunciation.  For example, many English-speakers have a hard time to pronounce a pure O sound without the little glidal W sound at the end of it.  It's just a habit in English that an O sound is followed by a little W sound.  The English word "no" sounds to a Spanish-speaker like "nou."

There are some people who have really flexible tongues like a parrot and can imitate any sound from a foreign language.
An Esperanto fan!  I always thought it would be a very interesting (and fun) language to learn.

Grape

"Grape" is Traube in German, raisin in French, uva in Spanish, acino in Italian, druva in Swedish, zabibu in Swahili, anggur in Indonesian, and budou in Japanese.  You can find these on an on-line multilingual dictionary.

"Grape" in Esperanto is vinbero, which really means "wineberry."

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Humans are born soft and weak.
They die stiff and strong.
The ten thousand plants and trees
Are born soft and tender,
And die withered and sere.

The stiff and strong
Are Death's companions.
The soft and weak
Are Life's companions.

Therefore,
The strongest armies do not conquer,
The greatest trees are cut down.
The strong and great sink down.
The soft and weak rise up.

--Tao Te Ching, Chapter 76
  Translated from Chinese by Stephen Addiss and Stanley Lombardo

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
The Force

These days there are lots of ideas from the East that are percolating in the West.  We hear about Yoga, Zen, Feng Shui, Tai Chi, et cetera.  It seems like a beginning of a synchretic new global civilization.  We live in interesting times.  The mixing of cultures is creating something new from something old.

Even the movie industry is affected.  Do you remember "Star Wars"?  We heard about the Force.  It sounds very much like the Tao in Taoism.  I have been reading up on the subject recently.  I quote from a website on Taoism:

Tao (pronounced "Dow") can be roughly translated into English as path, or the way. It is basically indefinable. It has to be experienced. It "refers to a power which envelops, surrounds and flows through all things, living and non-living. The Tao regulates natural processes and nourishes balance in the Universe. It embodies the harmony of opposites (i.e. there would be no love without hate, no light without dark, no male without female.)"

Then in "Star Wars," there is the good and bad like the Yin and Yang of Taoism.  There is the unity of opposites.  I find all the philosophizing very interesting.  Lots of people, many of whom were children, saw the "Star Wars" series, which must have had an impact on their minds and worldview.  Estu la Forto kun vi.  (May the Force be with you.)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: To Ninja:  I've recently been reading up on Taoism.  Here's a good source:  http://www.clas.ufl.edu/users/gthursby/taoism/ .

To Ninja:  One fascinating aspect of Taoism is wu wei, which means non-action or non-doing.  Basically the philosophy is going with the flow, not going against the flow of nature.  It is doing the least to achieve an effect.  It is not struggling against the stream.

Estu la Forto kun vi.
I'll have to use that in a poem.

Estu la Forto kun vi.
I'll have to use that in a poem.

The sequel, "The Te of Piglet" gets into it a bit more deeply and was, I felt, too mystical for my tastes. Visit http://gweezlebur.com/pooh/ and http://100acrewood.cjb.net/ and http://www.just-pooh.com/tao.html for some further discussion of Taoism and Pooh.

I remember reading an article entitled "The Tao of Star Wars" that I found somewhere online, it said pretty much the same thing. I have also read that Shinto, the Japanese belief, is also very similar to the ideas of "The Force" and that it was one of George Lucas's inspirations. And as for "Estu la Forto kun vi", I'm going to have to remember that.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
La Verda Stelo, The Green Star

This is the Esperanto flag.  Supposedly, if you see a person with a green star on his or her lapel, you could speak Esperanto, the aspiring International Language, to him or her.  Saluton [sah-LOO-tohn] is to say "Hello."

Esperanto is mainly a language for idealists and intellectuals, but because it is quite easy to learn, it is naturally designed for the masses.  The history of Esperanto stretches back to 1887 upon its first publication by its author and inventor L. L. Zamenhof.  Because of Esperanto's controversial idealism, many of its speakers were persecuted in the past.  Many governments around the world opposed Esperanto.  The prewar and wartime Japanese government persecuted Esperantists because "Esperanto speakers are like watermelons--green on the outside but red [Communist] on the inside."  In 1938, registered speakers of Esperanto in the Soviet Union were deported to Siberia or shot.  Esperanto was banned in the Soviet Union until 1956.  In the early 1920's, the teaching of Esperanto was banned in the schools of France.  In 1922, Adolf Hitler declared Esperanto a tool of Jewish world domination.

A simple idea of a universal second language that is easy to learn provoked much controversy as it still does today.  Today Esperanto is still much alive.  Many people would try to quash it.  Many claim that English is already the de facto international language, but English is really difficult for non-natives to learn.  Anyway, there are estimates of anywhere from 1 to 15 million speakers of Esperanto around the world today, depending on proficiency.

For me, it's just a hobby.  I'll let others deal with the politics.  I see the language Esperanto more as a work of art, much like an appreciation for poetry.

To Mystical2:  Every word in Esperanto is spelt phonetically.  There's a one-to-one correspondence between sound and symbol.  That's a good thing for bad spellers.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Karaoke

I'm quite amazed at how this word "karaoke" is pronounced in English:  "kah-rey-OH-kee."  I chuckle when I hear it.  Sometimes, out of conformity, I would pronounce it this way even though, with my one-year university training in Japanese, I know it should be "kah-rah-OH-keh."  Yes, it's a little thing, but it sticks out in my mind.

I lived and worked in Tokyo for a year.  I remember when I would go out nights with Japanese friends and co-workers to bars and each person would have to take a turn singing.  I'm not much of a singer.  So I opted to sing easy songs from The Beatles.  But I did sing "La Bamba" one time.  I didn't like to be forced to sing though.  Ja, mi memoras tiun tempon.  (Indeed, I remember that time.)

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
One Thousand Years

What would life be like in 3001?  Perhaps technology would be so advanced that a person from today could not imagine it.  "Any sufficiently advanced technology will seem like magic," said writer Arthur C. Clarke.  Just think that a person from 1001 could not possibly envision the Internet.

Would people still wear ties a thousand years from now?  I despise wearing ties.  Perhaps by then, the business suit will be obsolete.  I hope so.  Maybe everyone will just wear jeans.

Mi nur esperas ke la mondo estos en paco.  (I just hope that the world will be at peace.)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Yes, I have hopes that the world will see that far into the future as it would be interesting to see the developments that have occurred in another 1000 years.
Interesting. I would like to be able to somehow see the changes to come.
in the year 3001, if man is still alive, I don't think they'll be wearing ties.

Unless they are fun ties... with interesting to look at "things" on them... I think somewhere in one of my logs in the Signs You Have Grown Up section... we came to the conclusion that jeans qualify as dressed up :-)

Golly--that's hard to fathom--3001!

My prediction is we can actually get inside the NET, through a password--visit and actually meet the people, like here in Xanga--face to face! This is only if we want to. There's still a security, so no one can just pop in as you log on. Wouldn't that be so awesome? :-)
To Pureza:  So there could be an "virtual space" created in the Net.  Since we could create worlds in virtual space, would humanity lose interest in "outer space"?
We'll all be naked except our ties!

Life in 3001? hmmm i think life in 3001 will be like what life is like in the dark ages maybe around yr 2500 people will be kill each other destroying the advance civilization they currently have. hehehe

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Today is like Christmas for me as two items landed in my mailbox:

Item 1.  Eight weeks later after ordering from an online bookstore, I receive today a book, French Stories.  It is a dual-language book with French on the left side and the English translation on the right side.  There are ten stories by famous French writers like Voltaire, Balzac, Gide, Camus, et cetera.  Now I can truly get serious with my study of French since I can compare the words directly.

Item 2.  A package arrives from the Kanada Esperanto-Asocio (KEA, Canadian Esperanto Association).  It contains my membership card and some brochures about Esperanto, the would-be International Language.  There's also a catalogue of Esperanto books available on order.  I joined KEA this year because I wrote an article for them in Esperanto for their news bulletin Lumo and I want to receive it, so I can see my work if they publish it.  He he.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Oooh I want Item #1.... :-)

Re #1, I know just how you feel! Today Amazon.com delivered Robert Louis Stevenson's "Travels with a Donkey in the Cevennes". As a special bonus, included in the book is "An Inland Voyage" a canoe trip through Belgium and Northern France which I did not know was included. Yes, Virginia, there is a Santa claus!
Thanks for the links to Esperanto-I studied a little bit. Maybe someday I'll take a course or something...

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Hot and Spicy

Some day, I want to go to India.  I want to visit the exotic temples and ruins there.  I've been to Egypt and Morocco, so I expect some similarities there.  People wear robes in all those countries.  It also gets hot in all those countries.

India is a timeless place, I imagine.  And the diversity of people, languages, and food is just remarkable there.  Probable mi devas ne trinki la akvon tie, sed eble varman teon.  (Probably, I shouldn't drink the water there, but maybe hot tea.)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: It is exciting to travel to new places.  I would love the chance to visit other places.  So far I have had to content myself with the US and Canada.  Sigh.
Sounds like it would be a great trip.

you visit me, i visit you.  So you want to travel to India, and you've been to Egypt.  I lived in Jordan.  Know where that is?  Right above Egypt to the right.  My dad is from there...

If you go to India...beware the mice and cows...my dad's brother in Jordan went to school there...he said it isn't too clean...but very interesting...:-)

You're right about the water, and the tea. India will share some characteristics with Egypt and Morocco, but it has strong Hindu and Sanskrit influence, whereas the latter two have strong Islamic and Arabic influence. Pakistan is just next to India, and already it feels different. It would be worth seeing both sides of it.

I would like to visit India, too. I met a young student from TamilNadu who is going to school at MU. Just listening to him talk about his home has really made me want to go.

I have even started reading some Hindu writings. Just out of curiosity.

Thanks for the eProps and the visit!

actually, the robes don't make you that much hotter.  in fact, if your robes are white, the high albedo (percentage of an object's ability to reflect light/heat) will keep you from getting too hot.  of course, in these countries women are forced to wear black, but that's cultural geography . . .

Only Time

My sleek, black Seiko wrist-watch is dying.  It's like a pet to me.  I've had it for eons, since la ovo de tempo (the egg of time).  I don't think it's the battery.  The watch finally needs replacing.  It is strange because a couple of days ago, I had a premonition that some day soon I would have to replace it.  It's very strange.

Everything is temporary.

Jabberwocky

I had a big, fat hamster when I was a kid.  His name was "Jabberwocky."  It is from a famous poem called "Jabberwocky" by Lewis Carroll.  Mi memoras.  (I remember.)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I wish you were fifty so I could be in love with you!

Boy did you just bring back good memories for me :-) My most favorite teacher had our entire class learn the poem by heart, and we performed it in the local Chorous Competition. We won, because she helped us make the words come alive ....

Thanks for the trip down memory lane
i had a hamster and it was stepped on :-(
I love Jabberwocky and it's one I can recite from memory. Crazy, fantastic sound in that poem.
