item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Beaches and Pyramids

A while ago I stayed at the Club Med resort in Cancun, Mexico.  I had a fabulous time.  There were buffet breakfasts, lunches, and dinners.  I went windsurfing, waterskiing, sailing, scuba-diving, and snorkelling.  The water was warm, inviting, and crystal clear.  The corals and fishes were a fiesta of colors.  The beaches were white like baby powder.  I saw turtles, freshly hatched from their eggs, crawl to the sea.  I saw the natives, who were descendants of the Mayans, speak their Mayan as well as Spanish.  I took a little plane into the inland jungle to visit Chichen Itza, the famous thousand-year old Mayan city of the pyramid.  I was in awe.  In my joking mind, I hear "Chicken Pizza" when I really hear Chichen Itza.  He he.

ovo:  egg.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Those are great photos of Cancun! I went to Cancun in 1994. I didn't stay at Club Med but I did stay down the road at the Oasis Cancun Playa. Cancun waters are quite pretty. Although, I wish I did more of the athletic water sports than try and enjoy myself all the time downtown.
i always get the words for grapes and eggs mixed up.   Am I just crazy?
To m_loaf:  I think you are thinking that "ovo" is Spanish.  It's not Spanish, it's Esperanto.  "Egg" in Spanish is "huevo."

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Smell of Incense

It was bright and sunny today.  I took a walk to a local landmark which is a Buddhist temple where local Chinese immigrants worship.  I go there for amusement.  It feels like I'm a tourist in some Asian country whenever I'm there.  The temple is a genuine Chinese temple with full ornamentation and orange-tiled roof.  Inside are beautiful golden statues of Buddha, in front of which are offerings of various fruits.  The smell of incense is always in the air.  I admire the foreignness of it all.

Anyway, I was wearing my blazing red T-shirt with the Coca-Cola logo in Hebrew letters.  In the temple gardens, I met a couple, tourists.  Pointing to my T-shirt, the lady said, "Does that say 'Coca-Cola'?"  I said, "Yes.  It's Hebrew."  The man said, "I think I have one like that.  Did you get that in Israel?"  I said, "No, I bought in Las Vegas.  There's a Coca-Cola store there that sells T-shirts in different languages, like Russian, Hebrew..."  Then the man started reading the Hebrew, "I think it says 'refreshing' or something."  I asked, "You can read it?"  The man said, "I could make out some of it."  I asked, "Are you Jewish?"  They said, "Yes."  That explained it.  At that point I should have said "Shalom," but I didn't.  The lady said, "Good day" and we parted.

I was intrigued to see a Jewish couple at a Buddhist temple.  And by coincidence, I was wearing a T-shirt with Hebrew writing on it.  I wondered how they felt about their Jewishness in a Buddhist setting.  They seemed open-minded about other people's faiths.  Once I brought my visiting cousin from Los Angeles to that same temple, but he wouldn't go inside to look.  I felt that he feared something, being a diehard Roman Catholic visiting some place of "pagan" worship.  Well, I don't worry.  Mi vere admiras la templon.  (I truly admire the temple.)

vizito:  a visit.

viziti:  to visit.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: You know...my girlfriend is Buddhist and I just realized how whack it is that I haven't visited her temple. What you wrote made me decide that I need to do that soon...

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Yellowing Pages

I have a thick, old dictionary published in 1914.  It's Nuttall's Standard Dictionary of the English Language.  The pages are yellowing and many words in there are not current anymore.  Still, it looks good on my bookshelf.

vorto:  word.

vortaro:  dictionary.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Since i\I love language so much (I am an English teacher by vocation) I think I would love this dictionary, too! Salud!
Have you noticed that books seem to radiate some type of energy? I'm glad you have that old dictionary on your shelf...books like that are good to have around you. :-)
To Jeurja: Yes, books have energy, and personality too!

yes they do! :-)

super cool!  i wish i had a tome of that magnitude.  (heh, hyper-active use of vocabulary)

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
At the Art Gallery

I was invited to a poetry reading last night by a Mexican friend.  It was my first experience to a poetry reading.  It was held in an art gallery.   I loaded up on the cheese hors d'oeuvres while I was there.  I met a small crowd of artists there, people with ideals and vision; I could understand their views despite some heavy accents.  It was a reprieve from the usual technobabbling technocrats to which I've been exposed.  People can be so different in their outlook on life.  I can see that more, especially these days.  Also reading other weblogs, I can see that more.

arto:  art.

arta:  artistic.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: wow!! that is really neat! what did you read??
To magg:  Well, I didn't actually read; I came to listen really.

That last part about everyone having different outlooks is really true. I find myself constantly amazed by that, too. I think we (as humans) take it for granted that everyone else doesn't look at things like we do. It's good that you seem really open-minded about peeping life from other individuals' points of view.
I like talking with people having a different perspective. It's exciting!
i think it is crazy how the changing of one letter can make a word mean something else.  I always liked the differences that using ser and estar made when using it with adjectives.

I've had tofu cheesecake.  Trust me, it's no substitute for the real thing ;-)
Damn. The depth of that statement is beautifully subtle.
